trans-unit.source: Specifies the data type of a field or property for use in an <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter"></xref>.
The following table shows mappings between <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleType> data types, Oracle data types, and .NET Framework types.
An Oracle `BFILE` data type that contains a reference to binary data with a maximum size of 4 gigabytes that is stored in an external file.
Use the OracleClient <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleBFile"></xref> data type with the <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref> property.
An Oracle `BLOB` data type that contains binary data with a maximum size of 4 gigabytes.
Use the OracleClient <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleLob"></xref> data type in <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref>.
An integral type representing unsigned 8-bit integers with values between 0 and 255.
This is not a native Oracle data type, but is provided to improve performance when binding input parameters.
Use the .NET Framework <xref href="System.Byte"></xref> data type in <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref>.
An Oracle `CHAR` data type that contains a fixed-length character string with a maximum size of 2,000 bytes.

Use the .NET Framework <xref href="System.String"></xref> or OracleClient <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleString"></xref> data type in <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref>.
An Oracle `CLOB` data type that contains character data, based on the default character set on the server, with a maximum size of 4 gigabytes.
Use the OracleClient <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleLob"></xref> data type in <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref>.
An Oracle `REF CURSOR`.
The <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataReader"></xref> object is not available.
An Oracle `DATE` data type that contains a fixed-length representation of a date and time, ranging from January 1, 4712 B.C.
to December 31, A.D.
4712, with the default format *dd-mmm-yy*.
For A.D.
dates, `DATE` maps to <xref href="System.DateTime"></xref>.
To bind B.C.
dates, use a `String` parameter and the Oracle TO_DATE or TO_CHAR conversion functions for input and output parameters respectively.

Use the .NET Framework <xref href="System.DateTime"></xref> or OracleClient <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDateTime"></xref> data type in <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref>.
A double-precision floating-point value.
This is not a native Oracle data type, but is provided to improve performance when binding input parameters.
For information about conversion of Oracle numeric values to common language runtime (CLR) data types, see <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleNumber"></xref>.

Use the .NET Framework <xref href="System.Double"></xref> or OracleClient <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleNumber"></xref> data type in <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref>.
A single-precision floating-point value.
This is not a native Oracle data type, but is provided to improve performance when binding input parameters.
For information about conversion of Oracle numeric values to common language runtime data types, see <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleNumber"></xref>.

Use the .NET Framework <xref href="System.Single"></xref> or OracleClient <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleNumber"></xref> data type in <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref>.
An integral type representing signed 16-bit integers with values between -32768 and 32767.
This is not a native Oracle data type, but is provided to improve performance when binding input parameters.
For information about conversion of Oracle numeric values to common language runtime (CLR) data types, see <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleNumber"></xref>.

Use the .NET Framework <xref href="System.Int16"></xref> or OracleClient <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleNumber"></xref> data type in <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref>.
An integral type representing signed 32-bit integers with values between -2147483648 and 2147483647.
This is not a native Oracle data type, but is provided for performance when binding input parameters.
For information about conversion of Oracle numeric values to common language runtime data types, see <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleNumber"></xref>.

Use the .NET Framework <xref href="System.Int32"></xref> or OracleClient <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleNumber"></xref> data type in <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref>.
An Oracle `INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND` data type (Oracle 9i or later) that contains an interval of time in days, hours, minutes, and seconds, and has a fixed size of 11 bytes.

Use the .NET Framework <xref href="System.TimeSpan"></xref> or OracleClient <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleTimeSpan"></xref> data type in <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref>.
An Oracle `INTERVAL YEAR TO MONTH` data type (Oracle 9i or later) that contains an interval of time in years and months, and has a fixed size of 5 bytes.

Use the .NET Framework <xref href="System.Int32"></xref> or OracleClient <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleMonthSpan"></xref> data type in <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref>.
An Oracle `LONGRAW` data type that contains variable-length binary data with a maximum size of 2 gigabytes.
Use the .NET Framework `Byte[]` or OracleClient <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleBinary"></xref> data type in <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref>.
When you update a column with the `LONG RAW` data type, an exception is thrown when you enter a value of `NULL` in the column.
The Oracle `LONG RAW` data type is a deprecated type in Oracle version 8.0.
To avoid this error, use the `BLOB` data type instead of `LONG RAW`.
An Oracle `LONG` data type that contains a variable-length character string with a maximum size of 2 gigabytes.

Use the .NET Framework <xref href="System.String"></xref> or OracleClient <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleString"></xref> data type in <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref>.

An Oracle `NCHAR` data type that contains fixed-length character string to be stored in the national character set of the database, with a maximum size of 2,000 bytes (not characters) when stored in the database.
The size of the value depends on the national character set of the database.
See your Oracle documentation for more information.

Use the .NET Framework <xref href="System.String"></xref> or OracleClient <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleString"></xref> data type in <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref>.
An Oracle `NCLOB` data type that contains character data to be stored in the national character set of the database, with a maximum size of 4 gigabytes (not characters) when stored in the database.
The size of the value depends on the national character set of the database.
See your Oracle documentation for more information.

Use the .NET Framework <xref href="System.String"></xref> or OracleClient <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleString"></xref> data type in <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref>.
An Oracle `NUMBER` data type that contains variable-length numeric data with a maximum precision and scale of 38.
This maps to <xref href="System.Decimal"></xref>.

To bind an Oracle `NUMBER` that exceeds what <xref href="System.Decimal.MaxValue"></xref> can contain, either use an <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleNumber"></xref> data type, or use a `String` parameter and the Oracle TO_NUMBER or TO_CHAR conversion functions for input and output parameters respectively.

Use the .NET Framework <xref href="System.Decimal"></xref> or OracleClient <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleNumber"></xref> data type in <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref>.

An Oracle `NVARCHAR2` data type that contains a variable-length character string stored in the national character set of the database, with a maximum size of 4,000 bytes (not characters) when stored in the database.
The size of the value depends on the national character set of the database.
See your Oracle documentation for more information.

Use the .NET Framework <xref href="System.String"></xref> or OracleClient <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleString"></xref> data type in <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref>.
An Oracle `RAW` data type that contains variable-length binary data with a maximum size of 2,000 bytes.
Use the .NET Framework `Byte[]` or OracleClient <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleBinary"></xref> data type in <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref>.
The base64 string representation of an Oracle `ROWID` data type.

Use the .NET Framework <xref href="System.String"></xref> or OracleClient <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleString"></xref> data type in <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref>.
An integral type representing signed 8 bit integers with values between -128 and 127.
This is not a native Oracle data type, but is provided to improve performance when binding input parameters.
Use the .NET Framework <xref href="System.SByte"></xref> data type in <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref>.
An Oracle `TIMESTAMP` (Oracle 9i or later) that contains date and time (including seconds), and ranges in size from 7 to 11 bytes.

Use the .NET Framework <xref href="System.DateTime"></xref> or OracleClient <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDateTime"></xref> data type in <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref>.
An Oracle `TIMESTAMP WITH LOCAL TIMEZONE` (Oracle 9i or later) that contains date, time, and a reference to the original time zone, and ranges in size from 7 to 11 bytes.

Use the .NET Framework <xref href="System.DateTime"></xref> or OracleClient <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDateTime"></xref> data type in <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref>.
An Oracle `TIMESTAMP WITH TIMEZONE` (Oracle 9i or later) that contains date, time, and a specified time zone, and has a fixed size of 13 bytes.

Use the .NET Framework <xref href="System.DateTime"></xref> or OracleClient <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDateTime"></xref> data type in <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref>.
An integral type representing unsigned 16-bit integers with values between 0 and 65535.
This is not a native Oracle data type, but is provided to improve performance when binding input parameters.
For information about conversion of Oracle numeric values to common language runtime (CLR) data types, see <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleNumber"></xref>.

Use the .NET Framework <xref href="System.UInt16"></xref> or OracleClient <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleNumber"></xref> data type in <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref>.
An integral type representing unsigned 32-bit integers with values between 0 and 4294967295.
This is not a native Oracle data type, but is provided to improve performance when binding input parameters.
For information about conversion of Oracle numeric values to common language runtime (CLR) data types, see <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleNumber"></xref>.

Use the .NET Framework <xref href="System.UInt32"></xref> or OracleClient <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleNumber"></xref> data type in <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref>.
An Oracle `VARCHAR2` data type that contains a variable-length character string with a maximum size of 4,000 bytes.

Use the .NET Framework <xref href="System.String"></xref> or OracleClient <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleString"></xref> data type in <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value"></xref>.
